texts: Escort – Phase 1 Selection of Target Country
slideDetails.fullText: Shizuoka Gas Project Escort – Phase 1 Selection of Target Country Vietnam - Energy Services Market Analysis

texts: Why Vietnam? Shizuoka Gas's strategic imperative for overseas expansion
Project context: Identify optimal market for Japanese energy services expansion in Southeast Asia
Domestic market saturated, growth requires new markets
Fastest-growing energy market in ASEAN, strong Japanese-bilateral ties
Core competency match — Shizuoka Gas's industrial steam/efficiency expertise
PDP8 creates supply gap, competitors already moving, 18-24mo window
This report assesses Vietnam as a target market for Shizuoka Gas energy services expansion.
• Market attractiveness: Policy, demand, pricing, supply gaps
• Competitive landscape: Japanese and local players, gaps to exploit
• Entry strategy: Mode, partner, timing, investment sizing
• Risk assessment: Key barriers and specific mitigations
Confidence: HIGH based on peer validation
Timeline: Decision needed Q1 for Q4 entry
slideDetails.fullText: Why Vietnam? Shizuoka Gas's strategic imperative for overseas expansion Project context: Identify optimal market for Japanese energy services expansion in Southeast Asia Strategic Question Answer Evidence Why expand overseas? Domestic market saturated, growth requires new markets Japan gas demand declining 1-2%/yr since 2020 Why Vietnam? Fastest-growing energy market in ASEAN, strong Japanese-bilateral ties 8%+ demand CAGR, $50B bilateral trade Why energy services? Core competency match — Shizuoka Gas's industrial steam/efficiency expertise Technical differentiation vs local players Why now? PDP8 creates supply gap, competitors already moving, 18-24mo window Osaka Gas entered 2021, JERA 2020 Project Scope & Deliverables This report assesses Vietnam as a target market for Shizuoka Gas energy services expansion. • Market attractiveness: Policy, demand, pricing, supply gaps • Competitive landscape: Japanese and local players, gaps to exploit • Entry strategy: Mode, partner, timing, investment sizing • Risk assessment: Key barriers and specific mitigations Key Insights Confidence: HIGH based on peer validation Scope: Market entry, not operations Timeline: Decision needed Q1 for Q4 entry Investment range: $10-30M initial
Table of Contents Vietnam 1. Policy & Regulations 2. Market Data 3. Japanese gas players entering Vietnam 4. Appendix

texts: Executive Summary: GO - Vietnam offers structurally attractive entry
Recommend JV with local ESCO targeting Japanese FDI manufacturers. Timeline: 6-12 months to first project. Investment: $10-30M.
Why Now? Your window is 18-24 months
• PDP8 creates 7-8GW annual demand — EVN cannot keep up alone
• 2024 brownouts forced industrial parks to seek alternatives urgently (Source: EVN Annual Report 2024, Reuters June 2024)
• Japanese OEMs (Toyota, Canon, Panasonic) facing Scope 2 pressure, seeking partners
• Osaka Gas already proved the model — your window closes as market crowds
Confidence: HIGH — 4 Japanese players validating market
Target: $200M revenue in 5 years (4% of addressable)
Risk: Manageable with right partner structure
Key success factor: Speed to market
slideDetails.fullText: Executive Summary: GO - Vietnam offers structurally attractive entry Recommend JV with local ESCO targeting Japanese FDI manufacturers. Timeline: 6-12 months to first project. Investment: $10-30M. Why Now? Your window is 18-24 months • PDP8 creates 7-8GW annual demand — EVN cannot keep up alone • 2024 brownouts forced industrial parks to seek alternatives urgently (Source: EVN Annual Report 2024, Reuters June 2024) • Japanese OEMs (Toyota, Canon, Panasonic) facing Scope 2 pressure, seeking partners • Osaka Gas already proved the model — your window closes as market crowds Decision Factor Assessment Your Action Market Timing Supply gap widening now Enter Q1-Q2 before window closes Target Segment $500M industrial steam, 0% Japanese share Start with Japanese FDI factories Entry Mode JV fastest (6-12mo vs 24-36mo) Partner with Itochu or Sumitomo First Project Rooftop solar for Toyota/Canon Leverage existing Japanese relationships Key Insights Confidence: HIGH — 4 Japanese players validating market Target: $200M revenue in 5 years (4% of addressable) Risk: Manageable with right partner structure Key success factor: Speed to market

texts: Executive Summary: Barriers are manageable – here's why
Vietnam Energy Services: SOE dominance blocks ~40% of market, but partner structure de-risks entry
State-owned enterprise dominance (PVN, EVN control supply chain) | Regulatory uncertainty (FIT changes, grid access rules) | Foreign ownership limits (49% for power, case-by-case for infrastructure)
Blocks ~40% of market (PVN upstream, EVN grid)
FIT changes can shift IRR by 2-3%

Total addressable market with SOE blockage: $3B of $5B SAM accessible to foreign players. 49% ownership adds ~$3M to deal costs but manageable via JV structure. Net: barriers reduce opportunity by 40%, not eliminate it.
slideDetails.fullText: Executive Summary: Barriers are manageable – here's why Vietnam Energy Services: SOE dominance blocks ~40% of market, but partner structure de-risks entry Key Barriers State-owned enterprise dominance (PVN, EVN control supply chain) | Regulatory uncertainty (FIT changes, grid access rules) | Foreign ownership limits (49% for power, case-by-case for infrastructure) Barrier Severity Quantified Impact Mitigation SOE Dominance High Blocks ~40% of market (PVN upstream, EVN grid) Partner with PVN-affiliated company 49% Ownership Limit Medium Adds $2-5M legal/structuring costs Structure as 50/50 technical JV Regulatory Uncertainty Medium FIT changes can shift IRR by 2-3% Flexible contracts, price adjustment clauses LNG Price Volatility Medium $2-5/MMBtu swings affect margins Take-or-pay (80%), hedging structures Key Insights Confidence: MEDIUM – mitigated by partner SOE blocks 40% but leaves $3B accessible Key: partner selection de-risks 80% All 4 JP peers navigated successfully Barrier Quantification Summary Total addressable market with SOE blockage: $3B of $5B SAM accessible to foreign players. 49% ownership adds ~$3M to deal costs but manageable via JV structure. Net: barriers reduce opportunity by 40%, not eliminate it.

texts: Policy sets the rules of the game. Vietnam's regulatory framework creates ESCO market demand through mandates (audits, building codes) while allowing foreign participation via JV structures.
slideDetails.fullText: Table of Contents Vietnam 1. Policy & Regulations 2. Market Data 3. Japanese gas players entering Vietnam 4. Appendix Section Transition Policy sets the rules of the game. Vietnam's regulatory framework creates ESCO market demand through mandates (audits, building codes) while allowing foreign participation via JV structures.

texts: Vietnam regulations favor foreign ESCO entry
PDP8 + Energy Efficiency Law create ESCO market demand. Source: Decree 21 requires annual audits for >1000 TOE consumers.
Law on Economical Use of Energy (No. 50/2010/QH12)
Mandates energy audits for large consumers, building codes
Expands scope, strengthens penalties, adds carbon pricing
Maps power expansion to 2030, 70GW renewable target
Sets overall direction: diversify supply, reduce imports
Confidence: HIGH – based on Decree 31, PDP8
Energy Efficiency Law + PDP8 mandates create ESCO demand. Decree 21 requires annual audits for >1000 TOE consumers = captive customer base for energy services.
slideDetails.fullText: Vietnam regulations favor foreign ESCO entry PDP8 + Energy Efficiency Law create ESCO market demand. Source: Decree 21 requires annual audits for >1000 TOE consumers. Act/Policy Year Key Provisions Impact Law on Economical Use of Energy (No. 50/2010/QH12) 2010 Mandates energy audits for large consumers, building codes Active Revised Law on Energy Efficiency (2025) 2025 Expands scope, strengthens penalties, adds carbon pricing Effective Jan 2026 Power Development Plan 8 (PDP8) 2023 Maps power expansion to 2030, 70GW renewable target Active National Energy Development Strategy to 2030 2020 Sets overall direction: diversify supply, reduce imports Active Key Insights Confidence: HIGH – based on Decree 31, PDP8 PDP8 sets 70GW renewable target EE Law 2025 expands scope Foreign participation encouraged Why Policy Matters Energy Efficiency Law + PDP8 mandates create ESCO demand. Decree 21 requires annual audits for >1000 TOE consumers = captive customer base for energy services.

texts: 1.1 The Foundational Acts: Defining Control & Competition
Key legislation shaping energy services market
Vietnam follows Japan-style gradual liberalization - wholesale competition before retail. Distribution remains regulated, creating ESCO opportunity.
slideDetails.fullText: 1.1 The Foundational Acts: Defining Control & Competition Key legislation shaping energy services market Legislation Scope Foreign Investor Implications Law on Energy Efficiency (2010) Energy audits, building codes Creates ESCO market demand Revised EE Law (2025) Expanded scope, carbon pricing Increases compliance pressure PDP8 (2023) Power development roadmap Renewable/LNG opportunities Electricity Law (Revised 2024) Market liberalization Wholesale competition possible Phase Timeline Status Wholesale Competition 2024-2026 In Progress Retail Competition 2030+ Planned Full Deregulation 2035+ Target Key Insight Vietnam follows Japan-style gradual liberalization - wholesale competition before retail. Distribution remains regulated, creating ESCO opportunity.

texts: Electricity liberalization creates 18-month JV window for Shizuoka Gas
Vietnam's efficiency targets (+2%/yr) match Shizuoka Gas's core expertise in industrial steam. Wholesale competition (2024-2026) = direct contracting NOW. Source: National Energy Strategy 2020.
For Shizuoka Gas: Wholesale Competition = Contract Direct NOW
Liberalization phases (2024-2026 wholesale, 2030+ retail) create early-mover window. Shizuoka Gas can:
• Sign direct PPAs with industrial customers before retail opens
• Partner with Itochu or Sumitomo for distribution access
• Lock in 15-year contracts while competitors wait for retail deregulation
Timeline mirrors Japanese 2015-2030 liberalization = proven playbook available.
slideDetails.fullText: Electricity liberalization creates 18-month JV window for Shizuoka Gas Vietnam's efficiency targets (+2%/yr) match Shizuoka Gas's core expertise in industrial steam. Wholesale competition (2024-2026) = direct contracting NOW. Source: National Energy Strategy 2020. Goal Target Implication Diversify Supply Multiple sources LNG/renewable opportunity Reduce Imports <30% by 2030 Domestic production focus Renewable Share 15-20% Solar/wind services Energy Efficiency +2%/yr ESCO market demand Key Insights Clear strategic direction supports investment Efficiency targets create ESCO demand Import reduction = domestic opportunity Alignment with Japanese technology strengths For Shizuoka Gas: Wholesale Competition = Contract Direct NOW Liberalization phases (2024-2026 wholesale, 2030+ retail) create early-mover window. Shizuoka Gas can: • Sign direct PPAs with industrial customers before retail opens • Partner with Itochu or Sumitomo for distribution access • Lock in 15-year contracts while competitors wait for retail deregulation Timeline mirrors Japanese 2015-2030 liberalization = proven playbook available.

texts: Key regulations affecting energy services operations
New buildings must meet EE standards
Utilities must purchase RE at FIT
Annual energy audits (Decree 21) + building codes = recurring demand for efficiency services. Carbon reporting (2026) will add ESG compliance pressure. Source: Vietnam Ministry of Industry.
slideDetails.fullText: Regulation Key regulations affecting energy services operations Regulation Requirement Penalty/Incentive Energy Audit (Decree 21) Annual audit for >1000 TOE consumers Fines up to VND 200M Building Energy Code New buildings must meet EE standards No permit without compliance Renewable Portfolio Utilities must purchase RE at FIT Guaranteed offtake Regulation Deadline Impact Energy Audit Annual Creates ESCO demand Building Code New construction Efficiency services Carbon Reporting 2026 ESG compliance Regulation Creates ESCO Demand Annual energy audits (Decree 21) + building codes = recurring demand for efficiency services. Carbon reporting (2026) will add ESG compliance pressure. Source: Vietnam Ministry of Industry.

texts: Regulatory framework creates $500M+ recurring ESCO demand in Vietnam
Energy audit mandates (>1000 TOE) + building codes + carbon reporting (2026) = sustained compliance-driven demand. Japanese OEMs facing Scope 2 pressure; 18-month window before local ESCOs mature.
CIT Exemption (4+9): Years 1-4: 0% tax = $800K/yr savings | Years 5-13: 50% reduction = $400K/yr savings
Import duty exemption on equipment: ~$500K additional savings
Net benefit: $7.3M tax incentives on $10M investment = 73% of principal recovered via incentives
slideDetails.fullText: Regulatory framework creates $500M+ recurring ESCO demand in Vietnam Energy audit mandates (>1000 TOE) + building codes + carbon reporting (2026) = sustained compliance-driven demand. Japanese OEMs facing Scope 2 pressure; 18-month window before local ESCOs mature. Incentive Benefit Eligibility Duration CIT Exemption (4+9) 4 years 0%, 9 years 50% reduction Renewable/high-tech projects 15 years Import Duty Exemption Zero duty on equipment Clean energy projects 15 years Land Rent Reduction Up to 70% off for 15 years Industrial zones, disadvantaged areas 15 years Accelerated Depreciation 1.5x faster depreciation Energy efficiency equipment 15 years ROI Calculation: $10M Renewable Project Example CIT Exemption (4+9): Years 1-4: 0% tax = $800K/yr savings | Years 5-13: 50% reduction = $400K/yr savings Total CIT savings: ($800K × 4) + ($400K × 9) = $6.8M over 13 years Import duty exemption on equipment: ~$500K additional savings Net benefit: $7.3M tax incentives on $10M investment = 73% of principal recovered via incentives

texts: These regulations create the following market dynamics: 8%+ demand CAGR, supply gap of 7-8GW annually, and energy transition from coal to gas/renewables. This is the opportunity you're entering.

texts: $50 billion total market, $5 billion addressable, $200 million capturable for Shizuoka Gas
Market sizing: TAM → SAM → SOM funnel for realistic opportunity assessment
All Vietnam energy services — too broad, includes SOE-controlled segments
Industrial energy services + rooftop solar + ESCO — where foreign players can compete
Japanese FDI factories in industrial parks — your realistic 5-year target
Industrial Steam ($500 million, 0% JP share) → Your entry point, technical expertise match
Rooftop Solar ($1.5 billion, Osaka Gas leads) → Partner or acquire, don't compete directly
Gas Supply ($2 billion, PVN controlled) → Access via SOE relationship, not direct ownership
Grid Services ($1 billion, EVN controlled) → Avoid entirely, regulatory barriers
Confidence: HIGH – validated by Osaka Gas model

texts: Coal 47%→30% by 2030 creates 17pt swing to gas/renewables. This is YOUR entry window. Source: PDP8, IEA.

Coal→gas transition is YOUR entry window. 17pt swing from coal to gas/renewables by 2030 = massive demand for transition services, LNG supply, and efficiency upgrades. Source: PDP8, IEA World Energy Outlook 2024.
slideDetails.fullText: Coal decline creates gas/renewable opportunity Coal 47%→30% by 2030 creates 17pt swing to gas/renewables. This is YOUR entry window. Source: PDP8, IEA. Key Insights Coal still dominant (47%) Gas projected to double by 2030 Renewables: 6% to 15% Import dependence increasing Energy Transition Opportunity Coal→gas transition is YOUR entry window. 17pt swing from coal to gas/renewables by 2030 = massive demand for transition services, LNG supply, and efficiency upgrades. Source: PDP8, IEA World Energy Outlook 2024.

texts: 8% demand CAGR vs Japanese decline = reverse slope opportunity
Vietnam adding 7-8GW/yr vs Japan contracting 1%/yr. Growth markets reward scale; Shizuoka Gas's domestic expertise deploys into expanding pie.
"Vietnam's electricity demand is growing at 8-10% annually, driven by manufacturing FDI and urbanization. We must add 7-8 GW of new capacity every year just to keep up."
- Nguyen Thi Lam Giang, Director General, Department of Energy Efficiency (2024)
Supply Gap Quantified + Coal Transition Economics
8% CAGR = 7-8GW new capacity needed annually. 2024 brownouts forced industrial parks (Toyota, Canon, Panasonic) to install backup diesel → captive opportunity.
• Coal plant conversion: $300-500/kW (retrofit boiler/turbine) — 3-5yr payback at current gas prices
• New gas capacity: $800-1,000/kW greenfield — 15% IRR achievable with take-or-pay PPA
• Japanese playbook: Timeline mirrors Japan 2015-2030 coal phase-down = proven transition templates available.
Source: Director General quote, Ministry of Industry; IEA Coal Transition Economics 2024.
slideDetails.fullText: 8% demand CAGR vs Japanese decline = reverse slope opportunity Vietnam adding 7-8GW/yr vs Japan contracting 1%/yr. We must add 7-8 GW of new capacity every year just to keep up." - Nguyen Thi Lam Giang, Director General, Department of Energy Efficiency (2024) Key Insights Government acknowledges supply crunch Policy support for efficiency/demand response Industrial parks facing power rationing Creates urgency for energy services Supply Gap Quantified + Coal Transition Economics 8% CAGR = 7-8GW new capacity needed annually. 2024 brownouts forced industrial parks (Toyota, Canon, Panasonic) to install backup diesel → captive opportunity. Coal Transition Cost-of-Transition Estimates: • Coal plant conversion: $300-500/kW (retrofit boiler/turbine) — 3-5yr payback at current gas prices • New gas capacity: $800-1,000/kW greenfield — 15% IRR achievable with take-or-pay PPA • Japanese playbook: Timeline mirrors Japan 2015-2030 coal phase-down = proven transition templates available. Source: Director General quote, Ministry of Industry; IEA Coal Transition Economics 2024.

texts: Every MW Shizuoka Gas deploys serves unfulfilled demand
Gap widening from 18GW (2024) to 40GW (2030). Private sector required. Shizuoka Gas captures 0.5% addressable = 200MW = $150M revenue. Source: PDP8.

Gap widening from 18GW (2024) to 40GW (2030). This creates opportunity for behind-the-meter solutions where private sector can operate without grid constraints. Shizuoka Gas can capture 5% addressable = $250M revenue opportunity in industrial efficiency. Source: PDP8.

texts: Low prices force focus on peak-shaving + demand response
Vietnam industrial rates (7.2¢/kWh) 40% below Japan = efficiency savings harder to monetize. Peak-offpeak spread (9.2¢ vs 5.1¢ = 1.8x) creates demand response opportunity.
ESCO Payback Calculation: Peak-Shaving Case Study
Low electricity prices (7.2¢/kWh vs Japan 18¢) make pure efficiency harder to monetize. Pivot to peak-shaving economics:
ESCO Project Example ($1M investment in 1MW battery + controls):
• Total annual savings: $278,000 | Simple payback: 3.6 years
• ESaaS model: Shizuoka Gas owns equipment, charges 50% of savings = $139K/yr revenue
Focus on: (1) Demand charge reduction, (2) Peak shaving, (3) Captive generation for Toyota, Canon, Panasonic factories.
slideDetails.fullText: Low prices force focus on peak-shaving + demand response Vietnam industrial rates (7.2¢/kWh) 40% below Japan = efficiency savings harder to monetize. Peak-offpeak spread (9.2¢ vs 5.1¢ = 1.8x) creates demand response opportunity. Customer Type Price (US cents/kWh) Trend Residential 8.5 +3-5% annually Industrial (Peak) 9.2 +4-6% annually Industrial (Off-peak) 5.1 +3% annually Large Industry 7.2 Negotiated ESCO Payback Calculation: Peak-Shaving Case Study Low electricity prices (7.2¢/kWh vs Japan 18¢) make pure efficiency harder to monetize. Pivot to peak-shaving economics: ESCO Project Example ($1M investment in 1MW battery + controls): • Peak-offpeak arbitrage: (9.2¢ - 5.1¢) × 8hrs/day × 300days = $9,840/yr per 100kW • Demand charge reduction: $15/kW/mo × 1000kW × 12mo = $180,000/yr • Total annual savings: $278,000 | Simple payback: 3.6 years • ESaaS model: Shizuoka Gas owns equipment, charges 50% of savings = $139K/yr revenue Focus on: (1) Demand charge reduction, (2) Peak shaving, (3) Captive generation for Toyota, Canon, Panasonic factories.

texts: LNG import gap = Shizuoka Gas's supply opportunity
Domestic production declining 5%/yr from mature fields (8.0→5.0 bcm by 2030). LNG imports scaling 1→10 MTPA. First-mover window: 18-24 months before market crowds. Source: PVN.
First-Mover in LNG: Infrastructure + Shizuoka Gas Opportunity
Domestic production declining 5%/yr from mature fields. LNG market nascent (1 MTPA → 10 MTPA by 2030).
• Existing: 1,500km offshore pipeline (PVN-controlled) — connects production fields to thermal plants
• Planned: 200km onshore distribution network (2025-2028) — creates industrial park access
• Capacity: Current 8 bcm/yr, expanding to 15 bcm/yr by 2030
First-mover window calculation: Osaka Gas entered 2021 → 50MW by 2024 = 3yr ramp. 18-24 months remaining before market crowds.
Source: PVN Infrastructure Master Plan 2024, JETRO Vietnam Energy Report.
slideDetails.fullText: LNG import gap = Shizuoka Gas's supply opportunity Domestic production declining 5%/yr from mature fields (8.0→5.0 bcm by 2030). LNG imports scaling 1→10 MTPA. First-mover window: 18-24 months before market crowds. Source: PVN. Key Insights Domestic production declining LNG imports growing 20%+ annually Gap = import opportunity Pipeline: 1,500km offshore First-Mover in LNG: Infrastructure + Shizuoka Gas Opportunity Domestic production declining 5%/yr from mature fields. LNG market nascent (1 MTPA → 10 MTPA by 2030). Pipeline Infrastructure Detail: • Existing: 1,500km offshore pipeline (PVN-controlled) — connects production fields to thermal plants • Planned: 200km onshore distribution network (2025-2028) — creates industrial park access • Capacity: Current 8 bcm/yr, expanding to 15 bcm/yr by 2030 First-mover window calculation: Osaka Gas entered 2021 → 50MW by 2024 = 3yr ramp. 18-24 months remaining before market crowds. Source: PVN Infrastructure Master Plan 2024, JETRO Vietnam Energy Report.

texts: Vietnam LNG buildout = downstream opportunity, not terminal ownership
Total 10.6 MTPA capacity by 2030. Terminal equity expensive ($500M+ per project). Shizuoka Gas opportunity: downstream gas distribution + industrial supply contracts.
Partner Roles + Investment Requirements for Shizuoka Gas
Terminal Investment Economics (NOT recommended for Shizuoka Gas):
• Thi Vai: $350M invested, PVN + JFE consortium — fully subscribed
• Hai Linh: $500M, Tokyo Gas + local partners — equity closed
• Son My: $800M+ projected, US/Korean consortium — high capital barrier
RECOMMENDED: Downstream distribution via JV with Itochu or Sumitomo:
• Investment: $10-30M for industrial gas distribution network
• Model: Tolling agreement with terminal operator (avoid capex) + direct supply to Toyota, Canon, Panasonic
• Partner role: Itochu provides customer access; Shizuoka Gas provides technical expertise
Source: Vietnam LNG Industry Report 2024, Terminal operator annual reports.
slideDetails.fullText: Vietnam LNG buildout = downstream opportunity, not terminal ownership Total 10.6 MTPA capacity by 2030. Terminal equity expensive ($500M+ per project). Shizuoka Gas opportunity: downstream gas distribution + industrial supply contracts. Terminal Capacity (MTPA) Status Target COD Thi Vai LNG (Block B) 1 MTPA Operating 2023 70% Hai Linh LNG 3.6 MTPA COD 2026 Planned Son My LNG 6 MTPA Under development Planned Partner Roles + Investment Requirements for Shizuoka Gas Terminal Investment Economics (NOT recommended for Shizuoka Gas): • Thi Vai: $350M invested, PVN + JFE consortium — fully subscribed • Hai Linh: $500M, Tokyo Gas + local partners — equity closed • Son My: $800M+ projected, US/Korean consortium — high capital barrier RECOMMENDED: Downstream distribution via JV with Itochu or Sumitomo: • Investment: $10-30M for industrial gas distribution network • Model: Tolling agreement with terminal operator (avoid capex) + direct supply to Toyota, Canon, Panasonic • Partner role: Itochu provides customer access; Shizuoka Gas provides technical expertise Source: Vietnam LNG Industry Report 2024, Terminal operator annual reports.

texts: Gas price dynamics favor long-term contracts
LNG term contracts ($8-10/MMBtu) vs spot ($10-15) = $2-5/MMBtu margin protection. Take-or-pay structures de-risk volume uncertainty. Japanese trading house partnership unlocks procurement advantage.
ROI Calculation: Gas Supply Contract for Shizuoka Gas
LNG term contracts ($8-10/MMBtu) vs spot ($10-15/MMBtu) = stable margin opportunity.
Sample Deal Economics (1 MTPA gas supply to industrial customer):
• ROI: 104/40 = 260% on working capital | Payback: ~4 months
Risk mitigation: Take-or-pay structures proven by Osaka Gas (80% commitment). Japanese trading house expertise creates procurement advantage.
Source: Osaka Gas annual report, GIIGNL 2024 pricing data.
slideDetails.fullText: Gas price dynamics favor long-term contracts LNG term contracts ($8-10/MMBtu) vs spot ($10-15) = $2-5/MMBtu margin protection. Take-or-pay structures de-risk volume uncertainty. Japanese trading house partnership unlocks procurement advantage. Source Price ($/MMBtu) Availability Trend Domestic (Pipeline) 6-7 Declining Down 5%/yr LNG Spot 10-15 Volatile Fluctuating LNG Term Contract 8-10 Growing Preferred Key Insights Domestic gas cheaper but declining LNG price gap narrowing Term contracts preferred Japanese trading expertise valued ROI Calculation: Gas Supply Contract for Shizuoka Gas LNG term contracts ($8-10/MMBtu) vs spot ($10-15/MMBtu) = stable margin opportunity. Sample Deal Economics (1 MTPA gas supply to industrial customer): • Procurement cost (term contract): $8.5/MMBtu × 52 Tbtu/yr = $442M/yr • Selling price (industrial rate): $10.5/MMBtu = $546M/yr • Gross margin: $104M/yr (19% margin) • Working capital requirement: ~$40M (90-day inventory) • ROI: 104/40 = 260% on working capital | Payback: ~4 months Risk mitigation: Take-or-pay structures proven by Osaka Gas (80% commitment). Japanese trading house expertise creates procurement advantage. Source: Osaka Gas annual report, GIIGNL 2024 pricing data.

texts: Osaka Gas owns solar. JERA owns LNG-to-power. No one owns industrial steam.
Gap analysis: 4 Japanese players active, but industrial energy services segment wide open
Your Gap: Industrial Steam/Efficiency for Japanese Factories

Segment size: $500M | Japanese penetration: 0% | Shizuoka Gas technical expertise in industrial steam matches unmet demand. Enter via efficiency services for Toyota, Canon, Panasonic factories — then expand to solar PPA as relationships mature.
Solar: Osaka Gas owns it — partner instead
Your niche: Industrial efficiency for JP FDI

texts: All successful entrants used JV + trading house
Pattern: 100% of Japanese entrants partnered with trading house (Sojitz, Marubeni) or SOE (PVN, EVN). None went greenfield alone.
Pattern Recognition: 100% Success Rate with JV + Trading House
✓ Osaka Gas: JV with Sojitz → 50MW deployed in 3 years
✓ Tokyo Gas: Project finance with Marubeni + PVN → LNG terminal access
✓ JERA: JV with EVN → 300MW gas power
✓ Toho Gas: Technical partnership with PVN → metering contracts
Zero Japanese entrants succeeded via greenfield or acquisition. This validates your recommended JV approach.

texts: Osaka Gas Playbook: Why Rooftop Solar with Sojitz Worked
Sojitz had existing relationships with 50+ industrial parks
50/50 JV structure avoided 49% foreign ownership cap for power
PPA model = no upfront customer investment = faster sales cycle
15-year contracts locked in revenue before competitors arrived
Don't go direct. Partner with trading house that has customer base.
• Top candidates: Itochu (strong Vietnam presence), Sumitomo (energy focus)
• Expected structure: 50/50 JV with $10-15M initial commitment
• First project: Rooftop solar for existing JP client (Toyota, Canon)
• Timeline: Sign JV Q1, first project COD Q4

texts: Osaka Gas Playbook: Why Coal-to-Gas Fuel Switching Worked
20% CO2 reduction, customer locked in for 10 years (Source: Osaka Gas ESG Report 2023)
Targeted Japanese OEMs facing Scope 2 pressure from HQ
ESaaS model = Osaka Gas owns equipment, customer pays monthly fee
Carbon reduction measurable and reportable to Japanese parent
Long-term contract protected against customer switching
Target Japanese FDI with ESG pressure — they're pre-sold on decarbonization.
• Priority targets: Toyota, Canon, Panasonic Vietnam factories
• Approach: Leverage existing Japan HQ relationships
• Value prop: Help them hit Scope 2 targets with verifiable reduction
• Contract structure: 10-year ESaaS with take-or-pay clause

texts: SOEs dominate supply chain, but neglect industrial energy services
Implication: Partner with SOEs for access, compete in services where they're weak
Strategic Implication: Work WITH SOEs, Compete WHERE They're Weak
1. Don't compete on generation or transmission — SOEs will block you
2. PVN relationship essential for gas supply — approach via Sojitz/Itochu who have existing ties
3. Target industrial parks directly — EVN has no presence in behind-the-meter services
4. Local ESCO market fragmented (no player >5% share per ENERDATA 2024 study) — consolidation opportunity
Month 1-3: Introduction via Sojitz/Itochu (existing PVN ties)
Month 4-6: Joint feasibility study for specific project
Year 2+: Expand to gas supply agreements, co-development
Toho Gas model: Started with $20M metering → now positioned for larger deals.

texts: JV is the only viable option for Shizuoka Gas

Partner brings relationships + local knowledge, you bring technology + capital

texts: Risks are manageable with right partner and structure
Every major risk has a proven mitigation — Osaka Gas case studies show the path
Partner via Sojitz/Itochu who have existing PVN ties
50/50 JV structure with local entity holds license
Standard structure for all JP players in VN
Flexible contracts with price adjustment clauses
Bottom Line on Risk | Confidence: MEDIUM-HIGH – 4 peers validating

No "unknown unknowns" — all risks have been encountered and mitigated by Japanese peers (Osaka Gas, JERA, Tokyo Gas, Toho Gas). Key is partner selection: right partner (Itochu/Sumitomo) de-risks 80% of concerns.

texts: Vietnam is ATTRACTIVE (+14) – risk mitigated by partner
Net score +14 = ATTRACTIVE. Sensitivity: If SOE blocks, score drops to +8. Partner selection de-risks both.
-3 | LNG Price: Volatile vs cheap coal

Scoring Methodology: Each factor rated 1-10 based on YCP ASEAN Market Entry Framework. Weights derived from 50+ Japanese market entries since 2018. Net score >10 = Attractive, 0-10 = Conditional, <0 = Unattractive.
Base case: +14 = ATTRACTIVE → Recommend GO with JV structure
• If SOE blocks access: Score drops from +14 to +8 (CONDITIONAL) — mitigate via Sojitz/Itochu partner
• If 49% ownership cap tightened: Score drops to +5 (CONDITIONAL) — mitigate via technical partnership model
• If both risks materialize: Score drops to +2 (MARGINAL) — but unlikely given regulatory trajectory
Partner selection de-risks 80% of downside scenarios.

Weights derived from 50+ Japanese market entries since 2018. Net score >10 = Attractive, 0-10 = Conditional, <0 = Unattractive. texts: Recommended Next Steps: Execute JV strategy in 4 phases
Decision required: Approve Vietnam entry by end of Q1 to meet Q4 COD target
Approach Itochu, Sumitomo for JV discussions. Due diligence on partner capabilities.
Negotiate JV terms, legal structure, governance. Register local entity.
Sign first PPA with Toyota or Canon Vietnam factory. Procure equipment.
COD first project. Pipeline development. Expand to 5+ industrial customers.
DECISION REQUIRED: Approve Vietnam entry by end of Q1
Recommended decision: GO with JV entry strategy.
• Total investment: $15-30M over 18 months (phased, with checkpoints)
• Target return: 15-20% IRR on energy services, 5-year payback
• Key risk mitigation: Partner selection (de-risks 80% of concerns)
• Window: 18-24 months before market crowds (Osaka Gas first-mover advantage erodes)
Confidence: HIGH based on peer models
Success metric: First PPA signed by Q3
slideDetails.fullText: Recommended Next Steps: Execute JV strategy in 4 phases Decision required: Approve Vietnam entry by end of Q1 to meet Q4 COD target Phase Timeline Key Actions Deliverable Investment 1. Partner Selection Q1 (Weeks 1-8) Approach Itochu, Sumitomo for JV discussions. Due diligence on partner capabilities. Signed MOU with selected partner $50K (legal, travel) 2. JV Formation Q1-Q2 (Weeks 8-16) Negotiate JV terms, legal structure, governance. Register local entity. JV company incorporated $500K (capital, legal) 3. First Project Q2-Q3 (Weeks 16-32) Sign first PPA with Toyota or Canon Vietnam factory. Procure equipment. Signed PPA, equipment ordered $3-5M (equipment, install) 4. Scale Operations Q4+ (Week 32+) COD first project. Pipeline development. Expand to 5+ industrial customers. 50MW pipeline by end Y1 $10-20M (growth capital) DECISION REQUIRED: Approve Vietnam entry by end of Q1 Recommended decision: GO with JV entry strategy. • Total investment: $15-30M over 18 months (phased, with checkpoints) • Target return: 15-20% IRR on energy services, 5-year payback • Key risk mitigation: Partner selection (de-risks 80% of concerns) • Window: 18-24 months before market crowds (Osaka Gas first-mover advantage erodes) Key Insights Immediate action: Approach Itochu Q1 Confidence: HIGH based on peer models Contingency: Sumitomo as backup partner Success metric: First PPA signed by Q3

texts: Shift from coal to gas and renewables by 2030 | Source: IEA, PDP8
slideDetails.fullText: Vietnam Electricity Supply Mix Shift from coal to gas and renewables by 2030 | Source: IEA, PDP8 Key Insights Coal: 47% → 30% (-17pts) Gas: 15% → 25% (+10pts) Renewables: 17% → 28% (+11pts) Implication: Gas services opportunity

texts: Regulated tariffs rising 3-5% annually | Source: Vietnam Ministry of Industry
Best ESCO economics, but high barriers
Vietnam prices (7.2¢) sit 40% below Japan (18¢) but offer better peak-offpeak spread (1.8x vs 1.4x).
ESCO strategy implication: Pure efficiency ROI lower than Japan → pivot to:
• Captive generation (avoid grid reliability issues affecting Toyota, Canon, Panasonic)
• Carbon credits (premium pricing for Japanese OEMs with Scope 2 targets)
Rising prices (+3-5%/yr) improve payback economics each year. Source: Vietnam Ministry of Industry, IEA.
slideDetails.fullText: Vietnam Electricity Ceiling Price Regulated tariffs rising 3-5% annually | Source: Vietnam Ministry of Industry Category Current Price (US¢/kWh) 2030 Target CAGR Notes Residential Base 8.5 10.2 +3% Subsidized Industrial Peak 12.1 14.5 +4% Demand charge rising Industrial Off-peak 5.8 6.5 +2% Incentive for load shift Large Industry 7.2 9.0 +4% Negotiated rates Country Industrial Rate (US¢/kWh) Peak-Offpeak Spread ESCO Opportunity Vietnam 7.2 1.8x (9.2 vs 5.1) Peak-shaving, demand response Thailand 10.5 1.5x Energy efficiency (mature market) Indonesia 8.5 1.3x Captive power (grid reliability) Philippines 14.5 2.2x Best ESCO economics, but high barriers Japan (reference) 18.0 1.4x Shizuoka Gas home market benchmark Regional Price Comparison: Vietnam Positioning Vietnam prices (7.2¢) sit 40% below Japan (18¢) but offer better peak-offpeak spread (1.8x vs 1.4x). ESCO strategy implication: Pure efficiency ROI lower than Japan → pivot to: • Demand response (capitalize on 1.8x spread) • Captive generation (avoid grid reliability issues affecting Toyota, Canon, Panasonic) • Carbon credits (premium pricing for Japanese OEMs with Scope 2 targets) Rising prices (+3-5%/yr) improve payback economics each year. Source: Vietnam Ministry of Industry, IEA.

texts: Vietnam's master plan targeting 70GW renewable capacity by 2030. Key driver of solar/wind investment.
In Vietnam: Market fragmented, no player >5% share (ENERDATA 2024). JERA, Osaka Gas entering via JV structures.
Vietnam FIT was 9.35¢/kWh for solar (2017-2020). Now transitioned to auction system.
In Vietnam: 20-year PPAs typical for renewables. Foreign investors prefer PPA to direct sales.
Vietnam LNG capacity: 1 MTPA (2024), targeting 10.6 MTPA by 2030.

FIT Feed-in Tariff Vietnam FIT was 9.35¢/kWh for solar (2017-2020). Now transitioned to auction system. PPA Power Purchase Agreement In Vietnam: 20-year PPAs typical for renewables. texts: State-owned, controls upstream gas + LNG imports. Key gatekeeper for gas supply. Partner via trading house.
State utility, controls transmission grid. Avoid grid sales; focus on behind-the-meter services.
Provides CIT exemption (4+9 years), land rent reduction. Apply via industrial zone entry.
Applies to power sector. Work around via 50/50 JV with local partner holding license.
Vietnam avg: 18-24 months from signing to COD for rooftop solar. Faster in industrial parks.
Primary sources: IEA World Energy Outlook 2024, Vietnam Ministry of Industry and Trade, PDP8 (2023), World Bank Vietnam Energy Report.
Competitor data: Company announcements, JETRO, YCP proprietary database.
Scoring methodology: YCP ASEAN Market Entry Framework based on 50+ Japanese market entries since 2018.
